Is the minister aware that under the tax package providers will only receive 81.5 per cent of the pension paid to residents, down from the current 85 per cent, to provide basic daily care to residents? Isn't it a fact that most nursing home residents who are pensioners are cared for by non-profit community service operators such as Catholic health care? When the compensation does erode, isn't it the case that this change will result in providers receiving $12 a fortnight less per resident to provide that basic daily care, inevitably leading to reductions in the quality of care provided to older Australians?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Evans for the question, and the answer to the question is that I can confirm that the rates of assistance will be reduced. Currently, the basic fee is 85 cents in the dollar for the maximum single rate age pension and, while the pension is being increased by four per cent as a compensation measure, the basic fee will not raise. So, effectively, the fee becomes 85c in each 104c per pension. Accordingly, the proportion of the pension represented by the fee falls from 85 per cent to 81.5 per cent. If you listened to what Senator Evans said you would get the impression that there is a massive reduction. In fact, statistically there is a reduction but the compensation mechanismsâ
âHa, ha!

âSenator Collins may not understand it. Obviously she does not because she laughs. There is a four per cent increase in the full age pension, and increased rates of assistance will be provided to ensure the recipients receive a real increase in their pensions of 1.5 per cent, thereby enabling them to receive a fair share of the benefits of the new tax system. Providers will be limited by legislationâSenator Chris Evans is play ing with statistics hereâto charging only 81.5 per cent or face the possibilities of sanctions being imposed if they exceed this amount. So there will be sanctions imposed. But, on the other hand, of course the providers will be compensated because they can claim all GST taxed items that are input items, so the cost of providing services will be decreased.

answer.para: It is obvious that the Labor Party have not addressed their understanding of the new tax reform system and do not intend to. They are bringing up these spurious items to scare the public. It is a scare campaign once again. The pension increase will see single age pensioners receiving an extra $15.50 per fortnight and pensioner couples an extra $25.50 per fortnight, which is a large increase in income for older Australians. This increase lifts the full pension rate above the minimum level of 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings that is already guaranteed in legislation by the government.

The implication of Senator Evans's question was that the providers will be worse off. If the providers are so much worse off, why is it that in Queensland people are now attempting to buy bed licences for $30,000 each? If they are facing this desperate situation where the providers are going to be worse off, why do they want to spend $30,000 a bed?

I suggest the Labor Party study the new tax reform program that we are introducing and support it in this parliament so that we can get on with it. It is the only program that will compensate people, will allow for the future and will allow taxpayers to have the major tax cuts that my colleague was talking about previously. Where is the Labor Party's policy on tax reform?

talk.start.para: âNone.
âThey offer no alternative, but they carry on with issues of this nature which are ill informed and ill understood and they create a scare campaign in the general public.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would remind the minister that these are concerns that have been raised by industry providers. His answer was totally incomprehensible. The key issue is: what is the government doing to ensure that older Australians do not suffer a reduction in the quality of their care because the compensation package is designed to erode over time and, as a result, nursing home providers will have their funding cut? Can the minister guarantee that community based aged care providers, such as the churches, will not have their real funding reduced when the compensation package does erode?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer was incomprehensible only to the ignorant and those who do not wish to understand. If Senator Evans had listened to what I had said, he would understand. He does not want to understand.

answer.para: The reality is that there are compensation mechanisms in place for those who are in nursing homes, and there are compensation mechanisms in place for the providers as well. The reality is that the Labor Party has no other alternative to what we intend providing and will provide if this legislation goes through the Senate.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. I refer the minister to his response to the World Heritage Bureau on Kakadu contained in his recently released 140-page report and, in particular, to his repeated description of that response as being needed `to correct errors of fact, science and law'. Is the minister aware that the first edition of this report by his department was printed and then pulped? Could the minister inform the Senate of exactly what the errors were of fact, science and law which made this last minute pulping necessary? Can he provide the Senate with an estimate of the cost of the printing and the pulping exercise?

âThe errors of law and fact were within the mission's report to the World Heritage Committee. It was those errors that had to be overcome by statements of correct fact and also with independent scientific verification.

answer.para: I am pleased to say that the honourable senator is in part true, in that we have pub lished the government's response to the request of the World Heritage Committee. That response is supported, as was requested, by a report from the Supervising Scientist, an independent statutory authority. The Supervising Scientist, in developing his report, took advice from such institutions as the CSIRO, the University of Melbourne and the University of New South Wales, and I am pleased to say that the outcome of that report is to confirm the Australian government's assessment that there is no scientific reason whatsoever why this project could not go ahead.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, on a point of order: I did not ask the minister what was in the report. I did ask what the cost of printing and pulping that report was.
âThere is no point of order.

âI thought the honourable senator was interested in getting to the truth of the matter, which is the government's response to the errors that were contained in the mission of the World Heritage Committee. Anyway, I am pleased to advise the honourable senator that the report and the independent scientific verification confirmed that the EIS process that was conducted for Jabiluka was quite correct in concluding that there were no environmental reasons why this project could not go ahead. That is not surprising because, for 18 years, we have witnessed the Ranger uranium mine operate in the same region quite safely according to the views of the Supervising Scientist.
âThere is a difference and you know it.

âMadam President, on a point of order: the minister is debating the matter and not answering my question. I ask you to direct him to answer the specific question, which was: what was the cost of pulping that report?
âI cannot direct the minister as to how he deals with the question. I can merely draw his attention to the question which was asked, and I invite him to do so.

âSenator Bolkus was correct in his interventionâthere is a differ ence between Ranger and Jabiluka. Ranger is an old mine, open cut, much larger footprint and, one would have thought, potentially more environmentally dangerous. Jabiluka is a small mine, underground and only 22 hectares of footprint in a park of 20,000 square kilometres.

answer.para: The difference is that Labor stood by for 13 years in office and said that Ranger was fine: `No environmental damage from Ranger.' But now, because Labor is out of government, suddenly Jabiluka is a great threat to this whole 20,000 square kilometres of park. That is the nonsense that has had to be overcome by the Australian government's response to the World Heritage Committee. I trust that, now that the response is on the public record, we are likely to get a fair and objective hearing by the committee in July. If that occurs, our facts will be found to be correct and this project will be permitted to go ahead with the support of the World Heritage Committee. On the issue of this pulping, I do not know of that and I will try to find some details.

talk.start.para: âThe minister finally got around to answering my question, and he did not have an answer. Could the minister also confirm that a second edition of the glossy report including colour photographs and maps of Kakadu was also pulped and that this too was a rushed job on penalty rates? What was the cost of this second report, and did it too contain errors of fact, science and law? I again ask the minister to explain to the Senate the problem with the first report. Can the minister now assure the Senate that there were no errors of fact, science and law in the third report, which eventually did go to Paris?

âI will make inquiries on the issue, but the important fact is that, now the Australian government has the correct facts on the record, this is a step towards a fair debate of the issues in Paris in July. A fair debate will demonstrate that the Australian government has taken every reasonable step to ensure that this development is safe to the environment and safe in terms of protecting cultural interests. That has been our process in relation to this particular matter, and we can be confident now that the out comes are in accordance with what we earlier stated.

subdebateinfo.title: Private Health Insurance: Rebate Advertising Campaign

talk.start.para: âI address my question to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Is the minister aware of the recent ACCC finding that the government's advertisements for the 30 per cent rebate could `potentially mislead the public'? Can the minister explain why the government not only spent over $7 million of taxpayers' money to promote the $1.7 billion a year rebate but also resorted to misleading statements to sell this policy? Can the minister confirm that, rather than stating `private health cover will now be 30 per cent cheaper for all Australians', the advertisements should have stated `private health cover will now be 30 per cent cheaper for families earning over $70,000'?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Reynolds for the question. Yes, it is true that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has expressed concern about the government advertising campaigns. However, it did not find it necessary to take action over these concerns. It took no action whatsoever. The current phase of the government's rebate advertising campaign is now complete, and the next phase of the campaign is being developed presently. The ACCC was concerned that the advertising did not clearly state that the rebate replaced the old Private Health Insurance Incentive Scheme and that people formerly receiving benefits under the Private Health Insurance Incentive Scheme may have expected to receive a further 30 per cent reduction in addition to these benefits.

answer.para: It is true, as has been stated on many occasions, that the charges change from time to time. Under the Labor Party, they increased 150 per cent in a short period of time and continued to increase. Press reports stating that some health fund members are not receiving the full 30 per cent rebate because they formerly benefited from the Private Health Insurance Incentive Scheme are false. The rebate scheme has replaced the Private Health Insurance Incentive Scheme. All members holding appropriate private health insurance policies are now entitled to a full 30 per cent reduction of their health insurance premiums, regardless of whether or not they participated in the old scheme.

No-one who was receiving the Private Health Insurance Incentive Scheme will be worse off under the new scheme. The majority of these recipients will be better off because they will now receive a full 30 per cent rebate whereas under the Private Health Insurance Incentive Scheme it was much smaller. Mass advertising does not contain the level of detail required by some health fund members.

talk.start.para: âNot if it is paid for by the taxpayer.

âIn any case, this is only one component, Senator Ray, of the rebate information campaign. Comprehensive material such as information kits, brochures and fact sheets have been distributed widely to help fund members and Medicare offices. This material clearly states the rebate scheme replaces the old Private Health Insurance Incentive Scheme. This information is also available through the federal government 30 per cent rebate information line, which has been heavily publicised through all television and print advertising.

answer.para: Nevertheless, Dr Wooldridge's department has written to all health funds to inform them of the ACCC position and to advise that advertising should not make representations and have words to the effect that premiums are now 30 per cent cheaper. Funds have also been asked to refer to the fact that the rebate replaces the Private Health Insurance Incentive Scheme.

The ACCC has also expressed concern that people who have policies with unregistered health funds may have expected to receive the rebate. The government has decided not to apply the rebate to people covered by such policies because they have not contributed and do not contribute towards the cost of the chronically ill and the elderly through the reinsurance arrangements. Funds have been advised that all advertising should refer to the two requirements for eligibility contained in the definition of an appropriate private health insurance policy: firstly, that the fund is a registered health benefits organisation and, secondly, that all people covered by the policy must be eligible to receive Medicare benefits.

Claims that $7 million worth of taxpayers' money has been wasted on halted rebate advertising are totally false. The entire budget for the promotion of the rebate is around $7 million, which is less than half of one per cent of the total private health insurance rebate program. The government has a responsibility to inform the public about new initiatives. I make no apology whatsoever for advertising an important entitlement that can do so much to ensure the sustainability of Australia's health system.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister also acknowledge that, in resorting to misleading statements to sell the 30 per cent rebate, the government has admitted a complete lack of confidence in its own product? Will the minister also admit that the $1.7 billion a year rebate will do little to improve Australia's health care system? Why is the government attempting to shift the responsibility for airing the misleading and deceptive advertisements to the Department of Health and Aged Care, particularly to its Secretary?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the first two questions is no and no. The answer to the third question is that it is not.

âMy question goes to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask Senator Hill: will the issue of West Papua be raised in talks between the Prime Minister and President Habibie today? In particular, will the Prime Minister be raising the issue of recent massacres of people aspiring to independence for West Papua, otherwise called Irian Jaya? Will the government raise with Indonesia the bill now being rushed through the Indonesian parliament to separate West Papua into three provinces in the run-up to the June elections as a means of thwarting the independence movement? Finally, will Mr Howard be expressing his distress that mob intimidation can have an impact on the aspirations for independence in West Papua above and beyond the impact it quite obviously has on him in regard to cricket?

âI have not seen anything to suggest that the issues of Irian Jaya will be raised by the Prime Minister in his talks over East Timor. I would think there is enough to discuss on the latter subjectâin particular, ways in which we can be more confident than not that a peaceful vote can occur in an open and free way on the issue of autonomy. That, as I understand it, is the reason for the discussions taking place in Bali. As I said, I have no indication of other matters but, as it has been raised by Senator Brown, I will pass that on to the Prime Minister and see if he wants to add anything at a later date.

âMadam President, I ask the minister a supplementary question. Does the minister have any further information on my earlier question of him of some months ago regarding threatening and harassment of West Papuan leaders following a visit to meet President Habibie on 26 February in Jakarta? Can he tell the Senate whether or not it is true that the Commissioner for Police has now banned even discussions of those meetings with President Habibie? Are there West Papuan leaders still in gaol as a result of earlier demonstrations for independence, and does the government have any information as to the wellbeing of those previously gaoled independence leaders?
âI do not have any new information on that, but again I will pass on Senator Brown's concerns.

subdebateinfo.title: Private Health Insurance: Rebate Advertising Campaign

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Ellison, the Special Minister of State. Can the minister explain how the Howard government developed and ran an advertising campaign that could, according to the independent watchdog, the ACCC, potentially mislead the public? Does the minister acknowledge that the government's advertisement, which states `private health cover will now be 30 per cent cheaper for all Australians', was plainly deceptive? Didn't every one of these misleading ads carry the line `Authorised by C. Ellison for the Commonwealth Government, Parliament House, Canberra'? What is your responsibility for this, Minister?

âOf course, I did authorise that advertisement. I reject any allegation that it was misleading. In fact, you will notice that the ACCC took no action against the government in relation to that advertisement. The campaign was not stopped as a result of any comment by the ACCC, as has been alleged by the opposition. In fact, the television campaign ceased on 13 February, the print advertising finished on 23 January and outdoor advertising finished on 6 April. Here we have a situation where the ACCC expressed a concern about the advertisement. It was not enough to take action against the government. Indeed, the campaign had come to its own conclusion, not as a result of any action by the ACCC. I authorised those advertisements and, when I authorised them, they were certainly not misleading.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, we have heard the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care say in question time today that the government was not trying to shift responsibility for these advertisements to the Department of Health or its Secretary. My question to you, Minister, is: as the person who authorised these ads which have been found to be both misleading and deceptive, do you take responsibility, or does some other minister take responsibility? What does the Westminster system of ministerial responsibility have to say about which minister in the Howard government should take responsibility for these false and misleading advertisements?

âI have already answered the question in that I have stated that I authorised that advertisement. But Senator Faulkner's supplementary question is based on a false premise, because they have not been found to be misleading or deceptive. That is not what the ACCC said. I would remind the Senateâ
âIt is; they said they were potentially misleading.

âI hear Senator Evans say `potentially misleading'. That is not a finding of something being deceptive or misleading. It is totally different. What the opposition are doing is trying to twist this to their own advantage. This has not been found to be a misleading advertisement.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Recruitment of Doctors

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Given the priority the Howard government has placed on solving rural health problems, will the minister please outline what the government is doing to assist the states with the recruitment of doctors for rural areas?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Ferris for the question and for her interest in his important field, because it is good news, great news, for people living in rural and regional Australia. I see my colleague Senator Ian Macdonald nodding his head with great satisfaction. The Minister for Health and Aged Care, Dr Wooldridge, recently made a public offer to all states and territories that the government would address immigration requirements which present difficulties for the medical registration of overseas trained doctors wishing to work in rural areas of Australia. Prior to the weekend, only two state ministers had responded to the offerâJohn Day in Western Australia and Rob Knowles in Victoria. Dean Brown from South Australia rang up this morning to say that there was a letter in the post. Western Australia and the Commonwealth have struck a deal to attract more doctors to rural and remote areas of that state.

answer.para: Doctors seeking entry to the scheme will be assessed by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners instead of undertaking the Australian Medical Council examinations. Their medical registration will be restricted to rural areas to practise for a period of at least five years. Dr Wooldridge has offered $500,000 to assist this recruitment initiative. As senators already know, it is the government's policy to allow all doctors registered by a state or territory medical board to have access to a provider number to work in rural and remote areas.

I would like to stress that this offer is open to all states and the Northern Territory. I note in today's Courier-Mail that my own state is keen to play catch-up, and I strongly encourage the Beattie government to contact the Commonwealth to strike a similar deal for Queensland. I am very disappointed, in fact, that contact has not yet been made. It is nearly three weeks since Dr Wooldridge made this offer to the states and Queensland, New South Wales and Tasmania do not appear to have moved on the issue. These states all have Labor governmentsâsurprise, surprise, Madam President! Wendy Edmond, the health minister in my own state of Queensland, was reported as saying that she will contact Dr Wooldridge today but she had not done so at 12.30 p.m. when I checked. Hopefully, something has occurred since then. It is important that all states and territories get on with it. I am delighted that Western Australia has been the first to take the bull by the horns on this difficult issue. I am very disappointed that some other states, including my own, have been slow to take advantage of this offer from the Commonwealth.

This offer comes on top of some much needed strategies introduced by this government to address the rural health crisis. They include the John Flynn scholarships at university departments of rural health, including at Mount Isa. I notice Senator Ian Macdonald again nodding his head about the Townsville medical school and the opportunity for students in that area. Senator Reynolds should be clapping her hands, Madam President, at that announcement coming from Townsville. There are more country kids getting into medicine. There are locum programs, Rural Workforce Agencies, and moreâso a lot is being done. But the Commonwealth can only do so much; the rest is up to the states. I urge all senators representing New South Walesâsuch as Senator Faulkner hereâTasmania and Queensland to put pressure on their state premiers to address the rural doctor crisisâbecause, Madam President, we are.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister confirm that the government has agreed to undertake a so-called financial and academic review of Greenwich University? Can the minister inform the Senate as to the form, terms of reference and time line of this review? Can he also confirm that the Norfolk Island administration has already privately committed itself to repeal the legislation if the review finds against Greenwich University?

âOn a point of order, Madam President: opposition spokesmen seem to have fallen into bad habits in the last week, Madam President. I ask that you remind them of their responsibility to ask questions through the chairâSenator Faulkner in particular and now Senator Carr.
âI am sure senators know that questions should be asked through the chair and answers should also be given through the chair. I would remind all senators of that.
âYou are just trying to drag back all that ground that Richard Alston lost.
âOrder! Senator Faulkner, I have called for order so I can ask the minister to respond.

âAs I have previously stated in the Senate beforeâand as the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, has statedâGreenwich University is the responsibility of the Norfolk Island minister responsible for higher education. This matter arose at the ministerial council of education ministers last week and as a result there has been endorsement of the course of action taken by the minister for education. As I previously advised the Senate, the department is taking steps to establish a committee, including representatives of the Commonwealth, the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the states and territories, to consider information and to provide information and advice to the minister for education.

answer.para: As to what the Norfolk Island government is doing, I cannot tell the Senate. I can say that there has been a course of action adopted by the Commonwealth in conjunction with the ministerial council, and it has the endorsement of that ministerial council of education ministers.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I can take it from the minister's answer that there has in fact been a review established into the decision to direct the Administrator of Norfolk Island as to the establishment of the Greenwich University. Does the government now also acknowledge that a mistake was made in that direction?
âWho by?

âBy Senator Ian Macdonald. Does it also acknowledge that there is a need to correct that mistake, as a result of the direct threat that the establishment of this university now poses to the international standing and reputation of Australia's higher education? âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. I am wondering if the minister can give us an assurance that the proposed amendments to ANZFA's A18 standards will not allow for the approval of genetically modified foods solely on the basis of overseas regulatory authorities. Is the minister aware that, under the US Food and Drug Administration, there are no compulsory testing regimes for adverse health or environmental effects of genetically modified foods, and that evaluation of new plant varieties and products under the FDA allows for industry to actually undertake testing at their own discretion? Does the minister agree that these regimes are certainly insufficient and that they will not be replicated in Australia?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Stott Despoja for the question because I think all of us share her concern about genetically modified food. To answer her question, the responsibility for determining whether foods are available to the general public is accepted by the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. No genetically modified food considered unsafe will be permitted on the market by the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. That is the criterion they accept. Standard A18, the standard that Senator Stott Despoja referred to, has a number of important features. There will be a general prohibition on the sale of foods produced using gene technology. The standard will list any foods produced using gene technology that are permitted for sale.

answer.para: Applications for inclusion of products in this standard will need to be made through the authority's normal application process. Approved foods will be listed in a table to the standard. Following an application to the authority, the safety for human consumption of food will be assessed according to the authority's publicly available safety assessment guidelines for foods to be included in standard A18, food produced using gene technology. During this assessment, the authority will also determine if the food will require mandatory labelling. Any special conditions on the sale of the food, such as mandatory labelling, will be listed in the table to the standard. The assessment of all foods which are the subject of an application with ANZFA are open to public review, and public comment is invited.

At the 17 December 1998 meeting of the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council, the majority of state and territory health ministers were in favour of broadening the existing mandatory labelling provisions of standard A18 to include substantially equivalent foods. This is what Senator Stott Despoja was referring to in the sense of whether foods would be permitted if they had been subject to study overseas. Specifically, the council requested that the amendment should mandate labelling in circumstances where the manufacturer knows the food contains genetically modified material and, if the manufacturer is uncertain about the food's content, the manufacturer is to indicate that the food may contain genetically modified material. If the manufacturer knows the product to be free of genetically modified material, there will be no requirement to so label the product, but it may be.

Health ministers also asked the Australia New Zealand Food Authority to develop for their further consideration the definition of the term `genetically modified food', recognising there are many food ingredients such as sugars and oils which can be made from genetically modified plants but are not themselves genetically modified. These issues, as well as being matters of concern to the Australia New Zealand Food Authority, are matters of concern to the state regulatory authorities and territories. The standard that I have mentioned comes into effect on 13 May this year and will require the safety assessment and approval of all genetically modified foods and labelling of genetically modified foods that are substantially different from their traditional food counterparts.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as followsâ
Senate Question Without Notice
DIVERSION OF ILLICIT DRUG: USERS TO TREATMENT
SENATOR GIBBS asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care without notice on 22 April 1999:

Minister, on what basis did the Prime Minister arrive at the estimate that the additional $55 million a year to be provided for treatment of heroin users diverted from the prison system would be sufficient to treat 300,000 addicts? Given that the average cost of heroin treatment is in the order of $5,000, is it not the case that the government has created false hopes among many heroin addicts and their families and that in fact there will only be funds for about 10,000 extra treatments a year?
SENATOR HERRONâthe Minister for Health and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

The details of the diversion program will have to be determined in close consultation with State and Territory Governments the NGO Sector Australian National Council on Drugs and other relevant experts, however it is anticipated that the program will:
* target all illicit drug users, not just heroin users;
* target illicit drug users early. That is, before they have an extensive criminal record and, in many cases, before they are actually drug dependent; and
* provide a range of appropriate interventions for users.

Illicit Drug users need a range of interventions to assist them to address their illicit drug use, depending on factors such as drug of choice, whether or not they are drug dependent, drug use and treatment history social situation and personal preference.

As such, it is anticipated that those diverted from the criminal justice system will access a range of services. Some may only be assessed and provided a brief educational intervention, while others may require outpatient counselling and/or detoxification. A smaller number of clients will require more intensive interventions such as methadone maintenance therapy (in the case of some dependent heroin users), or residential rehabilitation. The cost of these various treatment options varies significantly, with residential treatment and methadone maintenance being the most expensive.

Premiers and Chief Ministers throughout Australia supported this important initiative at the Council of Australian Governments meeting on 9 April. The initiative builds on diversion programs currently being trialed in a number of States.

Health and Law Enforcement Ministers from each jurisdiction will be discussing this initiative further at the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy meeting scheduled for June and reporting back to COAG for their further consideration.
SENATOR GIBBS asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care without notice on 22 April 1999

Given that the minister is standing by the Prime Minister's assertion that 300,000 addicts will be treated with the additional funds, will he undertake to provide to the Senate the current average cost for treatment of heroin addicts and the statistics on which the 300,000 figure is based?
SENATOR HERRONâthe Minister for Health and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

The cost of treatment for illicit drug use, including heroin, varies significantly from State to State and from treatment type to treatment type, For examples the benchmark price for residential rehabilitation quoted by the Victorian Department of Human Services and Health in May 1998 was approximately $7000, while the cost of counselling, consultancy and continuing care was approximately $340.

The figure of 300,000 refers to the total number of interventions which may potentially occur. The range of interventions might include assessment only, education, outpatient services and residential services.

Different treatment options are appropriate for different people, depending on factors such as drug of choice, whether or not they are drug dependent, drug use and treatment history, social situation and personal preference. As such, it is anticipated that those diverted from the criminal justice system will access a range of services. Some may only be assessed and provided a brief educational intervention, while others may require outpatient counselling and/or detoxification. A smaller number of clients will require more intensive interventions such as methadone maintenance therapy (in the case of some dependent heroin users), or residential rehabilitation. The actual mix of treatment services required will need to be determined in close consultation with State and Territory Governments and local agencies.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) and the Special Minister of State (Senator Ellison), to questions without notice asked by Senator Evans and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senate Faulkner) today, relating to the government's private health insurance rebate.

In its decision, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission reviewed the advertisements paid for by the government promoting their rebate scheme. The commission said that the quote which was used widely in the adâthat is that `private health cover will now be 30 per cent cheaper for all Australians'âcould potentially mislead the public. The commission also found that it would have a flow-on effect on the advertising of the rebate by private health funds. The reason the commission did not take action is that the government undertook to end the campaign. The government said that the campaign had been finalised and that the billboard advertising would be removed; therefore, there was no possible remedy that the ACCC could take because the campaign had finished. The real issue here is why the government spent $7 million of taxpayers' money running a highly misleading campaign that has a lot of Australians angry and confused about the rebate. They knew it was misleading. They knew that it was not going to provide 30 per cent cheaper rebates for all Australians, but the ads continually said that private health insurance cover would be 30 per cent cheaper for all Australians.

They knew that was not true. Their own figuresâtheir own advice from the departmentâled them to the conclusion that that was not true, but they still spent $7 million of your and my money trying to push that line down the throats of Australians. They deliberately misled them. It is not bad enough that they have wasted $1.7 billion of taxpayers' money on a scheme that the private health insurance industry now admit will not workâwill not result in an increase in membershipâthey then threw another $7 million of taxpayers' money at it, misleading the Australian public about what was delivered in the rebate.

What we do know is that only about half of the people who benefit from this scheme will get 30 per cent cheaper health cover. The 2.4 million Australians who are eligible under the previous PHIIS do not get 30 per cent cheaper cover, and a number of people have written to me about this. The fact is that 2.4 million Australians do not get 30 per cent cheaper coverâmany of them do not get cheaper cover at allâyet the government spent $7 million misleading them about that. A number of people who have been to see me have been very angry about it because they believed what the government told them. They believed that the TV ads, the newspaper ads and the billboards were accurate. Of course, they were not accurate. The ACCC has found that they were not accurate, and the government does not seem to care.

There is no mention of an apology. There is no suggestion of accepting that the wrong thing has been done. We get the lawyers answer from Senator Ellison todayâhe tries to duck and weave. But the ACCC found that the government misled the public in claiming that private health insurance will be 30 per cent cheaper, and the government intend to do nothing about that because they have got away with it. Their line is, `The campaign is over and we got away with it, so what does it matter?' I think it does matter. I think it is an important public policy issue. It is an important issue about the expenditure of public moneys.

The minister is prepared to spend public money knowingly misleading the public. The government had this information. The department had provided it in terms of the debate we had on the bill. They knew they were misleading the Australian public and they still spent taxpayers' money doing it, for political advantage. The only families who get 30 per cent benefit from the measure are those who are on over $70,000 a year. The benefits of 30 per cent cheaper cover go to the top end of town. That is the truth about the new scheme. It is directed largely at the top end of townâthose on family incomes over $70,000. That is where the benefit goes. (Time expired)

I have never in all my life heard witnesses before an inquiry being called liars to their faceâby Senator Knowles. She is now trying toâ

âMadam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Crowley cannot just stand up here and say whatever she wants to say when it is untrue. I ask her to withdraw that accusation, as she will not find that word in Hansard in those hearings anywhere.
âYou checked did you?

âNo way; I am trying to get on with this speech.

speech.para: Senator Knowles interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Knowles, I will have some order. You have raised a point of order, and I will rule on that point of order. I do not need any assistance. Some of the things you have raised, Senator Knowles, are a debating point. If Senator Crowley has used those words in reference to you, then she is out of order and should withdraw them, but I did not quite hear the terms in which she used them.

âMadam Deputy President, I have a point of order. I asked you before to ask Senator Crowley to withdraw those words.
âSenator Knowles, Senator Crowley has not accused you of lying. If you think you have been misrepresented, then the appropriate time to take that up is at the end of this particular session.

âThank you, Madam Deputy President. It is interesting the lengths we will go to so as not to allow the opposition to speak on this matter. The government say that they did not really mislead the Australian people by promoting advertisementsâat the cost of $7 million precious public taxpayer dollarsâwhich claim that private health cover would now be 30 per cent cheaper for all Australians. speech.para: One of the reasons that the government has had to do something about private health insurance is that, under Medicare, Australians actually worked out that private health insurance would fall from 70 per cent to 30 per cent. And it was not 30 per cent; it was much higher than that. Senator Knowles was skating thin with the truth there. The point is that most Australians realise that Medicare was their salvation. For the first time ever, Australians were protected from big health bills. The two million people who were uninsured before the Labor Party came into government now, for the first time, had protection. Never again would they face health bills that meant that they were crippled or which meant that many of them went sick and avoided going to the doctor. That is what Medicare did. That is why the Australian people opened their arms to Medicare and said, `This is fantastic.'

The only way you can get a bill in health care now is if you have private health insurance. That is why the government is desperate to get some kind of gap insurance. People are leaving private health insurance because it does not deliver the goods.

Senator Knowles interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou keep company with the top end of town, you legislate for the top end of town; that is exactly what you are doing with this rebate.
âAddress the chair, please, Senator Crowley.

speech.para: What you should be doing with the $1.7 billion is not underwriting the rich and the top end of town with their private health insur ance, you should be putting it directly into the public hospitals so that the thousands and millions of Australians who need health care can get it. Why are they doing that? Because they are trying to change health away from the benefit of all Australians and that is their biggest crime. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âYes, we are super-sensitive on this side of the chamber and I am sure that Senator Knowles is as well. We are super-sensitive about implementing in policy the will of the Australian people. The reality is that the Australian people want a private health insurance scheme and they want a viable health insurance scheme. The government's 30 per cent rebate will provide more than six million Australians with private health insurance assistance and will provide a great incentive for many more to join.

speech.para: Private health insurance provides the choice that Australians want in their health system and should be entitled to. It also takes the pressure off public hospitals. Opinion research conducted some time ago by Morgan and Banks for health insurer MBF found that more than two-thirds of the community supported the introduction of a rebate for private health insuranceâthat is two-thirds of the community. What does it tell you that the ALP still does not support it? In fact, compendium research conducted every two years for the industry by Tony Quinton Associates has consistently found that a 25 to 30 per cent reduction was needed to bring more people into private health insurance. All Australians will benefit from the government's 30 per cent rebate.

In March 1998, research showed that health and hospitals are the number one concern for Australians today. I suggest that you hear that on the other side because I do not think that has been reflected in some of the petty point scoring that has happened today. While over half of the respondents rated the overall health system positively, two-thirds of the population believed that it was declining and needed serious help.

Improving health care for all Australians has been a key element of the Howard government's program since it was elected in 1996. The drop-out rate of private health insurance coverage is a primary influence on the responsiveness and effectiveness of health care. Private health insurance declined by more than half from 1983 under the ALP government.

We have just heard that two-thirds of the Australian public is in favour of it; let's hear a little about the ALP's record in this area. In particular, in 1993 former Senator Graham Richardson, the then minister for health, warned that private health cover rates were declining and that something needed to be done to ensure the system did not totally collapse. He said:
We've got to look seriously at how we get the numbers in private health cover up. It was 70 per cent when we came to office and it is about 40 per cent now. The drop last year was dramatic.
This was their own health minister at the time. He continued:
If the drop continues at any rate like it has been over the next few years, it won't be long before there will be enormous pressure on the public health system.
That was Graham Richardson in 1993. Even after he left the Senate, however, Graham Richardson was still having something to say about it and lamenting the ALP's stand. He said:
Everyone has to lose some battles but I wish I had won this one.
Now the Liberal Party is putting forward the same idea.
Even the thought that the Liberals are prepared to make the rich pay more, when the Labor Party would not, is enough to scare the hell out of me.
That was Graham Richardson in August 1996. However, he continued his interest in the area in November 1998. He restated his frustration with his former colleagues and said:

There's an ideological bent here that says Medicare is perfect which is ridiculous and therefore nothing should be done about private health which is also ridiculous. What they don't want to acknowledge is that as these people are dropping out of private health insurance they are simply queuing up at the public health system to be looked after. I wish Labor would stop this silly notion that it doesn't matter if private health care collapses, because I tell you what, we're within five years of a complete collapse of private health care, a total collapse.
That was Graham Richardson in 1998. A supporter of our introduction of a rebate for private health insurers.

Mrs Macklin is no better. She talked about the millionaires, the new species of elite AustraliansâMacklin's millionaires. She said that families on $70,000 a year are the rich, the elite. Well I have got news for Mrs Macklin. Families on $70,000 a year, when two people are earning an income, are only earning the average weekly wage in Australia. It's a disgrace that the ALP takes its pettiness out on average Australians. (Time expired)

The petition of the undersigned shows that citizens of Tasmania think that the government's taxation package, including the goods and services tax, does not provide sufficient information nor detail and hence is open to inequitable application during its implementation.

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
Restitution: A Basic Human Right

More than fifty years after the holocaust, Jews around the world continue to fight for and receive restitution for material and non-material losses inflicted by the Nazi regime throughout Europe. More than fifty years after the Palestinian people were displaced and dispossessed by an exclusive Jewish state established in Palestine in the aftermath of Nazi atrocities in Europe, Palestinians are still being dispossessed, dispersed, and denied any kind of restitution. Restitution is a universal human right. Persons now fighting for restitution are therefore to be supported.

We, the undersigned, believe that Palestinians, of whom two-thirds are refugees, also have the right of restitution, including the return of the rightful owners to their property as well as restitution for other material and non-material losses. Resolution 194, which recognises the right of refugees to restitution, has been reaffirmed one hundred and ten times by the United Nations. Further, as recently as November 1998, the UN General Assembly reaffirmed in Resolution 52/644 the principle, based on the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and international law, that Palestinian refugees are entitled to all revenues from their property.

We appeal to all fair-minded people, governments, parliamentarians, human rights groups and particularly Jewish organisations, to recognise, support and call for restitution of Palestinians through the restoration of homes and properties to their rightful owners as well as restitution for other material and non-material losses. While restitution can never fully make amends for all losses, suffering, and crimes against humanity, restitution establishes a precedent which should prevent the repetition of such catastrophes in the future.

The statements read as followsâ
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE WINTER SITTINGS
CRIMINAL CODE AMENDMENT (BRIBERY OF FOREIGN PUBLIC OFFICIALS) BILL

Early passage of this Bill is necessary so that Australia will remain in step with other countries of the OECD as they move to prohibit the bribery of foreign public Officials.. The USA, Germany, Japan, Korea, Canada and 7 other countries have already passed similar legislation designed to implement the OECD Convention on Combating Bribery of Foreign Public Officials in International Business Transactions. Most other OECD countries have similar legislation in the process of being considered by their parliaments, so early consideration is necessary if Australia is to avoid criticism. It would be unfortunate if Australia was seen by the international community to be equivocal about opposition to corruption.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Justice and Customs)
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE WINTER SITTINGS
CRIMINAL CODE AMENDMENT (SLAVERY AND SEXUAL SERVITUDE) BILL

Early passage of this Bill is necessary as it is important that the Commonwealth Parliament should provide leadership to the States and Territories. The Commonwealth Minister for Justice and Customs has been urging State and Territory Governments to enact complementary laws. It is therefore important that the Commonwealth component Of the scheme be in place as soon as possible. Senators will recall a similar Bill was before the Parliament prior to last year's election, so there have already been considerable delays in enacting the type of protection the Government is seeking to provide for young people contained in the Bill.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Justice and Customs)
DRAFT STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1999 WINTER SITTINGS
COPYRIGHT AMENDMENT (COMPUTER PROGRAMS) BILL 1999

This legislation will allow Australian businesses to decompile computer software for three purposes, namely, to make interoperable software and hardware products, to correct errors in software, particularly the year 2000 computer date problem (Y2K) and to test the security of their information systems.

This amendment of the Copyright Act 1968 is a crucial step forward in creating a legislative environment that will benefit both the information industries, particularly the software development industry, and business in general in the information age. The government's decision has taken account of the 1995 report by the Copyright Law Review Committee which recommended the introduction of a limited right to decompile in certain circumstances.

The government has decided that, with regard to error correction, the legislation will be retrospective to 23 February 1999, the date of the announcement of the decision, in an effort to assist companies resolve their Y2K problems.

Foreign information technology companies have been able to decompile software and hardware to make interoperable computer programs for some years, placing the Australian information industries at serious competitive disadvantage. The European Communities adopted a Directive allowing decompilation in 1991 and the US Digital Millennium Copyright Act enacted late last year recognises US case law allowing reverse engineering. Several countries in the South-East Asian region have also realised the importance of allowing this exception to copyright infringement by appropriate amending legislation.

Australian industry, particularly the information industries, has strongly welcomed the Government's decision and is anxious for legislative certainty regarding the scope of activities it might undertake as a result of the decision. This is of particular importance for achieving Y2K compliance. In the absence of legislation, industry currently can rely only on the media release announcing the decision.

The recent impact of the `Melissa' virus demonstrates the importance of security analysts having access to tools to enable them to quickly identify, track and neutralise unauthorised access to computer systems. The decompilation amendments will help companies protect their information systems against attack.

Urgent legislative action is necessary to allow decompilation so that industry has available to it as soon as possible another aid to combating the Y2K bug. With only eight months to go until the year 2000 anything that further helps Australian companies achieve Y2K compliance should be provided without delay. This legislation is also particularly timely with regard to its potential to boost the competitiveness of the Australian information industries.
(Circulated with the Authority of the Attorney-General)

para.inline: Accountability Principles 1998 and the Accreditation Grant Principles 1998 made under section 96-1(1) of the Aged Care Act 1997

speech.para: 18 February 1999
The Hon Bronwyn Bishop MP
Minister for Aged Care
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the following Principles made under s.96-1(1) of the Aged Care Act 1997 .

The Principles set out various aspects of the access to a residential care service which an approved provider of that service must afford to a person authorised by the legislation to undertake a review of that service.

The note to section 1.8 points out that an approved provider who refuses consent to a representative's access to the service, or withdraws that consent, may suffer one of the sanctions referred to in Part 4.4 of the Aged Care Act 1997 . However, these Principles impose no obligation on a member of the Department, or a person seeking access to the service, to advise the provider of that fact. The Committee suggests that it may be appropriate for the Principles to require that such information should be given to providers.

Section 1.12 forbids an approved provider from impeding access by a representative, and the latter's ability to make inquiries, so long as the access and questioning is relevant and necessary. The section does not, however, indicate who is to decide the relevance and necessity of that access or questioning, nor when a decision on those matters may be made.

These Principles set out the procedures to be followed, and the matters to be taken into account, by the Aged Care Standards and Accreditation Agency when it assesses residential care services, and the conditions to which the grant of accreditation is subject.
Subsection 2.6(1) permits the accreditation body to appoint a person to be an approved assessor, but does not provide for any qualifications or attributers that such a person should possess.

Paragraph 2.6(2)(b) requires the accreditation body to ask the service to provide information relevant to the assessment, but does not oblige the service to provide that information. If it did so provide, there would appear to be no safeguards as to whether the provider of the service should be required to incriminate him or herself, nor whether the provider may be assisted by a legal representative, nor the nature of the sanctions for refusing to comply with the request.

Section 2.8 permits the accreditation body to distribute an assessor's report to `anyone who asks for a copy', without any limitation which might be required for the protection of the privacy of the service which has been assessed.

Subsections 2.9(4) and (5) grant to the accreditation body the discretion to decide whether a residential care service complies with the Residential Care Standards. It may be suggested, however, that there is no need for independent review of the exercise of this discretion, since the decision of the accreditation body has no effect of itself. All that this body can do is to recommend to the Secretary that sanctions be imposed under the parent Act, and if the Secretary makes such a decision, it is reviewable under Part 6.1 of the Act. In such cases, the Committee considers that service providers should be advised of their rights of review before an accreditation body commences an inspection in the process of coming to a recommendation.

Subsection 2.9(5) requires the accreditation body and the service provider to agree on various matters. The subsection would appear to express no more than a hope, rather than an enforceable obligation, and indeed subsection 2.9(6) recognises that agreement may not be reached. Perhaps subsection 2.9(5) could be expressed more accurately.

Subsection 2.9(7) permits an accreditation body to continue to supervise a residential care service while the Secretary is considering his or her decision. It is not clear whether this continued supervision includes the right of the accreditation body to enter the relevant premises. Without a right of entry, the supervision would appear to be of little value, but if there is an implied right of entry, there are no safeguards to protect the provider of the service.
The Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Minister for Aged Care
Parliament House
The Hon Bronwyn Bishop MP
Canberra ACT `600
Telephone: (02) 6277 7280
Facsimile: (02) 6273 4138
Senator W.G. O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Bill,

Thank you for your letter of 18 February 1999 concerning questions on the Accountability Principles and the Accreditation Grant Principles arising from the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances (the Committee).

As you may know, these abbreviated Principles were gazetted on 22 July 1998 to ensure that the accreditation body, the Aged Care Standards and Accreditation Agency (the Agency) and its staff are covered for the purposes of monitoring residential aged care services. The Agency has no accreditation capacity until the full version of the Accountability Principles and the Accreditation Grant Principles are approved. The full versions are currently being prepared.
The abbreviated Accountability Principles and Accreditation Grant Principles will be repealed and replaced with the full versions once these are approved.
My response to the matters raised by the Committee, in the order that they were raised in your letter, is as follows.

The Committee refers to the note to section 1.8 which points out that a refusal of an approved provider to give consent to access to a residential care service by a representative could constitute a failure to comply with responsibilities in relation to accountability under Part 4.3 of the Aged Care Act 1997 (the Act).
More specifically, I note that it is a responsibility:
. under paragraph 63-1(1)(j) of the Act to allow persons authorised by the Secretary access as required under the Accountability Principles to review the certification of a service; and
. under paragraph 63-1(1)(l) of the Act to allow people acting for accreditation bodies access to a service as specified in the Accountability Principles, and
. under paragraph 63-l(l)(m) of the Act, to comply with `with such other responsibilities as are specified in' the Accountability Principles.

However, it should be noted that section 1.13 of the Accountability Principles sets out a number of circumstances in which refusal to give access does not constitute a failure to comply with responsibilities under the Act.

Where there is such a failure by an approved provider to comply with responsibilities under the Act, it renders an approved provider liable to possible sanctions action under Part 4.4 of the Act. Given this, the Committee's suggestion that the Accountability Principles should require that approved providers be informed of this (presumably at the time access is requested) is appropriate.

I agree with the Committee' s suggestion and consider that it could be accommodated by requiring that the letter giving notice of intended access in section 1.7 refer to the fact that failure to consent could lead to sanctions action. Representatives permitted under subsection 1.7(2) to give notice orally could also be required to state this. Further, there could be a requirement in section 1.9 that the letter of authority identifying a representative also state that a consequence of failure to consent to access could, in some circumstances, lead to sanctions action.

Given that the full versions of the Accountability Principles and the Accreditation Grant Principles are currently being prepared, I propose to instruct the Department to put these requirements into effect administratively until they can be incorporated into the full version of the Accountability Principles.

The Committee refers to the prohibition of an approved provider from impeding a representative's access and ability to question various persons where this is `relevant' and `necessary' as set out in section 1.12. The Committee notes that there is no indication of who decides such relevance and necessity.

However, this provision has to be read with paragraph 1.13(c) which provides that it is not a failure to comply with responsibilities as an approved provider to refuse access to a representative `because the representative's conduct is inconsistent with section 1.12'. Requirements of relevance and necessity in section 1.12 are therefore stated in objective terms.

If sanctions are imposed for failure to comply with section 1.12, it will be the Secretary's delegate deciding this who will address what was relevant and necessary. That delegate's decision would also be subject to internal review and review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal under section 85-8 of the Act.

The Committee points out that the `approved assessor' who must assess a residential care service is merely, as defined in section 2.3, a `person approved as an assessor for a residential care service' There is no specification of the criteria for such approval such as the qualifications required for approval.

I accept that approved assessors exercise important functions of gathering evidence upon which decisions of considerable significance to approved providers and care recipients will be made. That evidence may well later fall to be considered by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the Federal Court. I therefore agree with the Committee that the qualifications of assessors should be specified. I will ensure that appropriate provision is made for this in the full version of the Accreditation Grant Principles.

The Committee notes that the accreditation body before an assessment must ask the residential care service `to provide any information relevant to the assessment' but that there is no obligation on the service to provide that information. The Committee then points out that, if there were such an obligation, it would appear necessary to have safeguards against self incrimination.

I note the Committee's comment on these matters. However, by providing such information, the residential care service is more likely to assist its own cause than by not providing relevant information to the assessor.

The Committee points out that a copy of the assessment report must be given by the accreditation body to anyone who asks for it without there being any limitations having regard to the privacy of the service which has been assessed'.

I note that the accreditation body must also publish the assessment report (section 2.7). Further, section 86-9 of the Act authorises the Secretary to make publicly available the kinds of information there specified about an aged care service. These include:
. information about the service's status under this Act (for example, the service's . . . accreditation . . . record); and
. `information about the approved provider's performance in relation to responsibilities under (the) Act' (paragraph 86-9(1) (k) and (l), respectively).

The material in an assessment report would be expected to fall within these descriptions, and to that extent, copies of the report could be made available by the Department. Because the making public of such information is a function of the Secretary under the Act, the function will need to be delegated to the accreditation body under subsection 96-2(6) of the Act. Given this, there seems no reason why there should not be an express provision in the Accreditation Grant Principles permitting an accreditation body to release the assessor's report.

The protected information provisions in Part 6.2 of the Act apply to an accreditation body in relation to information acquired in the performance of duties under the Act. Where the accreditation body is performing functions of the Secretary as specified in the Accreditation Grant Principles (in accordance with paragraph 80-l(l)(b) of the Act) information acquired in so doing is protected information under the Act. The assessment of compliance with Residential Care Standards is such a function. Therefore, the protected information provisions of the Act not only authorise the making public of the relevant kind of information, but operate generally to protect it in the hands of an accreditation body.

I have been advised that the publication of similar reports (to those proposed to be published under section 2.7 of the Accreditation Grant Principles) was permissible under the National Health Act 1953 (subsection 45DA(2) in particular). The rationale for such provisions is that it is in the community's (and especially care recipients' and their relatives') interest to be fully informed about standards at relevant residential care services so they can make informed decisions about residential aged care.

The Committee refers to the requirement that the accreditation body `recommend to the Secretary that sanctions under the Act be imposed' if it is not satisfied at the conclusion of an improvement timetable that the level of care provided by a residential care service complies with residential care standards. The Committee points out that such a recommendation has no effect of itself. Any subsequent sanctions action will be reviewable under Part 6.1 of the Act. The Committee considers `that in such cases' service providers should be advised of their review rights `before an accreditation body commences an inspection in the process of coming to a recommendation'.

However with respect, the accreditation body does not know, nor could it know, before commencing an inspection that the case is one where a recommendation of sanctions' action by the Secretary' s delegate will ensue. In the vast majority of cases, this would not be expected to be the result. In addition, Part 4.4 of the Act contains detailed provisions for the giving of notices as an integral part of procedures for the imposition of sanctions by the Secretary's delegate. In my view, there is ample opportunity for approved providers to be informed of their rights should a case reach such a level.

The Committee refers to the requirement that the accreditation body and the approved provider `must agree' on arrangements for the supervision of the service. If agreement is not forthcoming, the accreditation body under section 2.6 must tell the Secretary and recommend that sanctions be imposed. The Committee is suggesting that the words `must agree' are inappropriate for something which, it is recognised, may not occur.

While I accept that words such as `must attempt to agree' would be more appropriate, I note that no legal consequences flow from this. However, I will ensure that this matter is considered in the preparation of the full version of the Accreditation Grant Principles.

The Committee refers to the function of the accreditation body of continuing to supervise the residential care service while the matter of a recommendation by the accreditation body to impose sanctions is being considered by the Secretary. The Committee says that it is not clear if this involves an implied right of the accreditation body to enter the relevant premises, and that, if it does, there are no safe-guards for the approved provider. The Committee also says that without such an implied right the `supervision would appear to be of little value' .

In supervising a residential care service, the accreditation body would rely on the same authorisation, based on the consent of the approved provider, contained in the Accountability Principles, as in carrying out its other functions. There is, having regard to those Principles and related provisions of the Act, no implied right to access conferred by this provision. In the event that, notwithstanding that sanctions under the Act could ensue, consent to entry is not forthcoming, it would be necessary for an authorised officer acting under warrant obtained under Division 92 of the Act to exercise monitoring powers under the Act.
Should you or the Committee wish to discuss any of these matters further, I and my staff would be more than happy to do so.
Yours sincerely
(Signed)
BRONWYN BISHOP

talk.start.para: âI table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as followsâ

This bill follows up last year's youth allowance package. That package consisted of two substantial acts and several pieces of subordinate legislation, including three major ones relating to the fares allowance for students, the student financial supplement and the youth allowance family actual means test.

Those three matters were addressed at the time in subordinate legislation only because of the time constraints imposed by the youth allowance package. As was always intended, those provisions are now to be moved into the Social Security Act itself, by this bill.

The provisions are to be moved in this way without generally making any change in their effect. This, of course, was also the aim when moving the provisions last year from the former AUSTUDY structure into the social security system, so that students did not suffer any disruption to their payments half way through the academic year. However, certain drafting and other minor refinements are to be made now, including to ensure that the original AUSTUDY provisions are correctly reflected.

The other main purpose of the bill is to deal with several technical issues that were identified during the implementation of the youth allowance package. Again, these reflect the original AUSTUDY policies and generally consolidate the operation of the package.
The bill also makes minor consequential amendments to relevant tax and data-matching legislation
I commend the bill to the Senate.
